description:
Regional Government of Castilla and Leon published a document on March 11 according to which the teaching practices in health and socio-health centers for students of vocational training cycles and university degrees are suspended, with the exception of those in the last year of studies in medicine and nursing who express their express consent in writing.

This policy ended on March 14 with the Royal Decree 463/2020 that declared the national state of alarm for the management of the health crisis situation caused by COVID-19. UPDATE: The original policy was supposed to end on March 26, but it actually ended on March 14 with the Royal Decree 463/2020  that declared the national state of alarm for the management of the health crisis situation caused by COVID-19.
type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
institution_status: Higher education institutions allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On March 12, the Generalitat of Valencia ordered the suspension of schools, universities and nurseries in the province. School teachers still have to go to their educational centers and it’s up to the directors to decide if they can work from home. This policy will enter into force on the 13th of March 2020 and does not have an end date. UPDATE: On March 14, the National Government of Spain announces a nationwide state of emergency. Due to this, all educational centers are forced to close under a national government mandate. This new national mandate replaces the previous where the Valencian Community mandated school closings.

description:
Government of Castilla and Leon published a document on March 13 where face-to-face teaching and extracurricular activities are suspended in centers of all educational levels. Regarding the university sphere, classroom teaching activity is also suspended and public and private university residences are closed, except for those foreign students who, due to force majeure, cannot return to their countries of origin and students who live with people at risk.
During the period of suspension of face-to-face teaching, it is recommended to continue the activities through the distance and online modalities.
type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
institution_status: Higher education institutions closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On March 12, the Prime Minister of Spain Pedro Sanchez recommends shutting down all educational centers for the next two weeks. The Government of Andalucia agrees to follow this recommendation, deciding to temporarily end "'face-to-face teaching'" starting Monday, March 16. This new national mandate replaces the previous, Andalucia mandated school closings.

institution_status: Higher education institutions closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On May 4, Andalusia enters Phase 0 of Spains deescalation plan. This means that how quickly the region is able to move through the deescalation plan, and therefore alter the restrictions put in place on educational facilities, depends on the Andalusian government. Therefore, all educational updates within the deescalation period will be coded subnationally.

description:
The Department of Education has prepared an opening plan for educational centers in Catalonia for the end of the current academic year and for the next academic year 2020-2021.
Regarding the dates of application of the plan in each center, they must be adapted to the progressiveness of the arrival of Phase 2 in each territory. 
-Nurseries, maximum 5 students per classroom. 
-Kindergarten and primary schools, maximum 13 students per group.
-ESO centers and post-compulsory education, in groups of 15 students maximum.

description: On June 11, the Spanish Ministries of Health and Education and Professional Training release a document, agreed upon by the autonomous communities, that declares a strategy "to offer a safe and healthy environment for students and staff of educational centers in order to resume face-to-face activity for the 2020-2021 academic year that begins in September." This strategy fundamentally revolves around "contact limitation, personal prevention measures, case management, and cleaning and ventilation."

description: Ximo Puig, president of Generalitat Valenciana, informed that on July 19, schools of the Valencian Community for kids up to 3 years old (i.e. preschool, kindergarten), whether public or private, can reopen and resume their activity. Also, summer schools can open with 75% of the normal student number (maximum capacity is 100 in closed spaces and 250 in opened ones). Additionally, elementary, middle and high schools must provide face-to-face tutoring to families by appointment. Also, they can carry out face-to-face activities in small groups for students who take the university entrance exams. Finally, university students can resume their internships.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On June 30, it is announced that "the Junta of Andalucia... will hire 6,300 extra teachers" for the 2020-2021 school year. These teachers will "serve as 'support' in schools with more than 20 students per classroom." In addition to the 6,300 teachers, 1,600 cleaners, alog with 152 "technical staff for social integration," will be hired. This initiative, combined with other general investments to improve the education system for the upcoming year (such as the Andalucian government giving 25 million pounds to schools "to expand or renovate their facilities and make them ready for emergencies") will cost the government around 600 million pounds.

institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

This initiative, combined with other general investments to improve the education system for the upcoming year (such as the Andalucian government giving 25 million pounds to schools "to expand or renovate their facilities and make them ready for emergencies") will cost the government around 600 million pounds.
type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
institution_status: Higher education institutions allowed to open with conditions

description:
In the Community of Madrid, Spain, starting July 1, 2020, students in the first cycle of child education may return to classrooms voluntarily, with preference for children whose parents must work outside the home. Daycare centers will continue to offer services that they have been offering since March 11.

University education will remain remote, but if an activity requires physical presence, a distance of 1.5 meters must be maintained. Universities must approve an action plan for the 2020-21 academic year.

description: On March 28, the city of Lozoyuela-Navas-Sieteiglesias in the Community of Madrid, Spain, initiated a curfew after 3 pm. People were only allowed out of the house from 9 am-3 pm, and all purchases needed to be at least 30 euros. The curfew began on March 28. No information is provided on an end date.

description: On April 25th, the Spanish government announces that, starting April 26th, “up to three children under the age of 14 accompanied by an adult, guardian or elder sibling … are now … allowed out for an hour a day to walk and exercise” between 9am and 9pm, with 2m social distancing required.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Spanish Health ministry announces on April 30 that starting from May 2, Spanish citizens aged 14-70 years are allowed to go out for a walk or exercise from 6 to 10 am and from 8 to 11 pm. The outing has to take place within one km from home (individual exercise excluded), with a distance of 2m from other people. Individuals under this demographic can go with max. 1 person living in the same household. In villages with less than 5000 inhabitants the different time frames don’t apply, everyone can go out under the same conditions between 6am and 11pm.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Spanish Health ministry announces on April 30 that starting from May 2, Spanish citizens aged 14-69 years are allowed to go out for a walk or exercise from 6 to 10 am and from 8 to 11 pm. The outing has to take place within one km from home (individual exercise excluded, as you only have to stay within your municipality), with a distance of 2m from other people. Individuals under this demographic can go with max. 1 person living in the same household. In villages with less than 5000 inhabitants the different time frames don’t apply, everyone can go out under the same conditions between 6am and 11pm.

description: The Spanish Health ministry announces on April 30 that starting from May 2, people who need special attention and people aged 70+ can go out between 7-8 pm accompanied by one person. The outing has to take place within one km from home, with a distance of 2m from other people. This time slot is in tandem with the 10-12 am time slot, with both acting as viable options for outside activity under this demographic. In villages with less than 5000 inhabitants the different time frames don’t apply, everyone can go out under the same conditions between 6am and 11pm.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 25, the Prime Minister of Spain announces that, starting May 2, people 14 or older (but less than 70/ not dependent) can take one-hour walks, accompanied by one person, once a day within half a mile of their homes, or do sports like riding a bike alone within their city. The timeframe set for this activity is between 6 a.m. to 10 a.m. (or 8 p.m. to 11 p.m.).

description:
On April 30, the Spanish government announced that, starting May 2, children under 14 are allowed to go out between 12-7 pm, accompanied by a parent. Only one outing a day is allowed for one hour maximum, and the outing has to take place within one km from home. In villages with less than 5000 inhabitants, these time frames don’t apply, and everyone can go out under the same conditions between 6am and 11pm.

 UPDATE: To coordinate with the deescalation of outside regulation for other demographics, the Spanish Health ministry announces on April 30 that starting from May 2, children under 14 are allowed to go out between 12-7 pm, accompanied by a parent. Only one outing a day is allowed. Children are allowed to stay out for one hour maximum. The outing has to take place within one km from home , with a distance of 2m from other people. Adults can go with max. 1 person living in the same household. In villages with less than 5000 inhabitants the different time frames don’t apply, everyone can go out under the same conditions between 6am and 11pm.

description: Spain on May 3 announces that starting from May 4 the, athletes may carry out training individually, in open air spaces, twice a day, between 6:00 and 10:00 and between 20:00 and 23:00, within the limits of the municipal area in which they have their residence. They will also be able to access the natural spaces that they require. However, these restrictions do not apply to elite athletes "designated as “high-performance” by the Superior Council for Sports."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 28, the Prime Minister of Spain announced that, beginning May 4, the nation would enter a gradual de-escalation period for the country's strict lockdown. As the de-escalation will take place "at a different, yet coordinated, rate" in each province, the severity of curfew restrictions per province largely depends on that particular environment, meaning the beginning of this plan therefore replaces the national curfew restrictions preceding it. (Additionally, due to the province-centric characteristic of the de-escalation measure, all advancements in the plan will be coded sub-nationally for each individual province.)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On May 3, the Government of Spain announces that, with the start of Phase 0 on May 4, athletes not "designated as “high-performance” by the Superior Council for Sports" but still "affiliated with clubs may train individually in the open air between 6am and 10am."

*As the 4-phase deescalation plan is asynchronous for each national region, whenever Andalusia enters a phase, it's effects will be coded sub- nationally.

description: On May 4, Andalusia enters Phase 0 of Spain’s 4-phase de escalation plan. Furthermore, the previously instilled curfew allowing people 14 or older (but less than 70/ not dependent) to exercise outside (on a bike within one's city or a one-hour walk within 0.5 miles of one's home) between 6 a.m. to 10 a.m. (or 8 p.m. to 11 p.m.) is now included in this Phase 0. Due to the asynchronous nature of the de escalation plan, this curfew is now viewed as a sub-national policy, as how long it lasts locally largely depends on how well Andalusia handles its virus environment.

description: Spain (Catalonia) on February 25 activated "the Catalan government’s strategy for dealing with emergencies associated with emerging communicable diseases that pose a high risk. The strategy is a tool to support inter-ministerial coordination, facilitate adoption of preventive measures, and share information in order to ensure that the response to any outbreak of communicable disease is as rapid as possible."

description: On March 16, Spain announced that, starting from March 17, external land borders will be closed with the neighboring countries of France and Portugal, and "only Spaniards, residents and citizens who cite force majeure will be able to enter national territory - Freight will still be able to enter the country in order to guarantee the supply of goods."

description:
On March 22, the Government of Spain announced that, starting March 23, entry for travelers "originating in countries from outside the Schengen area" will be restricted at air and sea ports for at least the next 30 days. Exceptions to this rule are:

a) Residents of the European Union or Schengen associated countries, who are heading directly to their place of residence.

b) Holders of a long-term visa issued by a Member State or Schengen associated country heading to the latter.

c) Cross-border workers.

d) Healthcare professionals or those who look after the elderly travelling to exercise their profession.

e) Personnel engaged in the transport of goods in the exercise of their profession and the necessary flight crew to perform commercial air transport activities.

f) Diplomatic and consular staff, personnel working for international organisations, the armed forces and members of humanitarian organisations in the exercise of their duties.

g) People travelling on duly accredited imperative family grounds.

h) People that can provide documentary accreditation of grounds of force majeure or situations of need, or whose entry is permitted on humanitarian grounds.

i) Spaniards and residents of Spain

(This policy exists on top of the still present cruise ship ban).
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

"The only exceptions to the ban are government aircraft as well as planes carrying medical or humanitarian aid." UPDATE: Instead of fully terminating travel restrictions with Italy on March 25, on March 24 it was decided that such restrictions would be loosened to "transport Spanish citizens back from Italy to Spain." (This change still constitutes as an end to the severely strict travel restrictions).
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: The Spanish Ministry of Health, on May 4, advises that U.S. citizens who are residents of Spain, and/or have access to long-term accommodation and the financial means to remain in Spain for an extended period, should not travel at this time.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
On May 12, the Spanish Government announced that, starting midnight on May 15, "entry into national territory at internal borders at ports and airports (for ships and planes originating in countries in the Schengen area)" will be restricted for at least 30 days, with exceptions to these border controls being: 
1. Spanish citizens.
2. Residents in Spain, accrediting their primary residence.
3. Cross-border workers.
4. Healthcare professionals or those who look after the elderly to exercise their labour activity.
5. Those people who can show documentary evidence of causes of force majeure or a situation of need.
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)

description: On March 25, the Government of Spain introduces looser restrictions in regards to travel from Italy to Spain. The goal of these looser restrictions is to allow the transport of Spanish citizens who were trapped in Italy due to the March 10 travel ban. The rest of the restrictions from the original March 10 travel ban still hold. UPDATE: On May 19, the Government of Spain lifts the "ban on all direct flights and ships from Italy" that had been in place since March 10. However, tourism and cruise ships are still restricted.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 12, the Government of Spain announced that, beginning midnight March 13, cruise ships would be banned from entering the country. This measure would be effective at least until March 27, with the possibility of extension. UPDATE: After being extended twice since its original March 13 introduction, on June 16, the Spanish Ministry of Transport announces that the restrictions will be extended to "foreign registered vessels and recreational boats unless manned by a professional crew and registered with an official board." Additionally, the overall ban is extended indefinitely.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On June 14, the Government of Spain announced that, starting June 21, the country will reopen its borders (ports and airports) with all European Union and Schengen-area countries (including the UK).
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)

description: Starting June 21, the only EU/Schengen Area nation that Spain continues to impose land border restrictions with is Portugal, with the same exemptions to this rule applying as they did with the original March 17 border resections. This will continue until July 1, when both countries agreed to reopen their land borders.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 16, Spain announced that, starting from March 17, external land borders will be closed with the neighboring countries of France and Portugal, and "only Spaniards, residents and citizens who cite force majeure will be able to enter national territory - Freight will still be able to enter the country in order to guarantee the supply of goods." UPDATE: On June 14, the Government of Spain announced that, on June 21, the country would reopen its land border with France. However, "on the request of the Portuguese government," the border with Portugal will be closed until July 1.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On July 4, the Government of Spain effectively reopens the countries external borders to a list of 12 countries recommended by the EU: Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, Montenegro, New Zealand, Rwanda, Serbia, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia and Uruguay (Cruise ships are still banned indefinitely, however). Additionally, the country is considering reopening the passage of citizens from Morocco, Algeria and China if there is reciprocity on the part of these nations and there is a permitted flow in the opposite direction. Finally, when regarding the rest of the world still restricted from entry, "some additional categories [for exemptions to the restriction] have been [introduced,] ... [with] the scope of [some exemptions already present] ...  [being] extended."
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Spain is developing a protocol for action in the event of the appearance of possible suspected cases of coronavirus in Spain on Jan 24. The aim is to review the situation, the epidemiological update, as well as the diagnostic capacity and response actions in Spain.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Spain (Catalonia) announced to treat mild cases of coronavirus from home on Feb. 29

description: Spain maintains the protocols for action against the coronavirus UPDATE: The Ministry of Health maintains the protocols for action against the coronavirus

description:
On March 15, the Government of Spain announced that, within the next 3 days, "autonomous communities must notify the Ministry of Health...  all the provisions and containment measures that the.. . competent authorities of the autonomous communities and local entities have adopted on the occasion of the coronavirus" up until March 14. These communicated measures include:
a) Limitations on the freedom of movement of people.
b) Establishments, equipment and activities whose opening to the public is
would have suspended or conditioned.
c) Ensuring the supply of products necessary for the protection of
public health.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 15, the Government of Spain imposes a policy stating that, periodically going into the future,  the "autonomous communities [of the country] must send the... Ministry of Health [information on the local] epidemiological situation, the situation of... healthcare capacity[,] and the needs for... [human and material] resources," with some of this information being required daily (i.e. number of cases) and some being required weekly (i.e. weekly consumption of materials).

description: Spain (pais vasco) has carried out the Covid-19 test to all the residents in the residences of Zadorra, Ariznabarra, Sallurtegi, Samaniego and San Prudencio, the latter of municipal competence. In addition, the same test has been carried out in 5 privately owned residences. The results will be available in the next few days announced on April 07
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On March 15, the Government of Spain imposes a policy stating that the "autonomous communities [of the country] must send the... Ministry of Health [information on the local] epidemiological situation, the situation of... healthcare capacity[,] and the needs for... [human and material] resources." UPDATE: On April 17, the Government of Spain imposes a modification on the March 15 order revolving around communication between the autonomous communities and the Ministry of Health. The point of this modification in the order is to adapt "to the evolution of the health crisis." Some of the modifications to the policy include an expansion of "the information related to the hiring of human resources," as well as a mandate that autonomous communities must now separate reports of symptomatic cases from asymptomatic cases.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Balearic Islands (Spain) Ministry of Health conducts a screening and diagnosis on all health professionals in the region to determine their proximity to coronavirus, and whether they have contracted it.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
Spain has introduced a de-escalation period on 4 May 2020 to guide the country back to "nueva normalidad" (new normality). This period ended on 21 June 2020.
It consists of four phases: 0 - preparation, 1 - initial phase, 2 - intermediate phase, 3 - advanced phase. Each region will progress to the next phase depending on strategic capacities of the healthcare system, the epidemiologic situation, the compliance with public protection measures and data on mobility and socio-economic details. The time to stay within each phase was initially set to 2 weeks for each province, but this was not always met in reality.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Spain (Balearic Islands) will conduct "diagnostic tests on all suspected cases [of coronavirus] and a contact study."
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On May 11, the "Ministry of Health [promotes]... a ministerial order that regulates the obligations and procedures for obtaining and communicating information for epidemiological surveillance related to COVID-19 during the transition phase towards a new normal." Essentially, this order sees the creation of a more relevant information collection system than before, and mandates specific ways of receiving data that are designed to facilitate the transition to a new normality. Several of these mandates are:

1. "The order obliges all health and social health centers, services and establishments, both in the public and private sectors, as well as the health professionals who work in them, to provide all the data necessary for the monitoring and epidemiological surveillance of COVID- 19 that are required by the competent health authority. " 

2. It "is also established that the autonomous communities and cities will guarantee that a PCR test or other appropriate molecular diagnostic technique is carried out on each suspected case of COVID-19 in the first 24 hours from the knowledge of the symptoms."  

3. As "of today, the public health units of the Autonomous Communities must obtain daily data on suspected and confirmed cases from the public and private systems, as well as from the occupational risk prevention services."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 8, the National Government of Spain announces that all of Andalucia except for the provinces of Málaga and Granada will transition to Phase 1 of the countries deescalation plan on May 11.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On March 15, the Government of Spain imposes a policy stating that, periodically going into the future,  the "autonomous communities [of the country] must send the... Ministry of Health [information on the local] epidemiological situation, the situation of... healthcare capacity[,] and the needs for... [human and material] resources." UPDATE: With the beginning of Spain's transition towards a new normality, the Ministry of Health decides to expand "the collection of epidemiological data from the Autonomous Communities," effectively replacing the previous policy regulating these measures.

description: Effective June 10th, Spain will require that "Interprovincial air and land transport operators" as well as "operators of maritime transport... with pre-allocated seating" will have to "collect contact information for all passengers and keep the lists a minimum of four weeks after the trip" in case one or more of the passengers gets Covid-19. They will also be required to "provide these lists to public health authorities when they are required, with the purpose of performing contact tracing."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Effective June 29th, Spain imposed health monitoring measures at airports and maritime ports of entry. All passengers who arrive at these points of entry will have their temperature taken with "no-contact thermometers or thermal cameras," in addition to undergoing a "visual inspection," and filling out an online "public health questionnaire" which will be presented through QR code upon entry. Tourist companies and airlines are responsible for reminding travelers about their "obligation to present the public health questionnaire at the airport or port of destination."  

"Passengers with a temperature over 37.5 ºC (99.5ºF)," or those that are "suspected to suffer from COVID-19 or another pathogen" based on the written and visual health inspections will be subjected to further health inspections to evaluate the risk they pose to public health. If suspicion of a public health hazard is confirmed, "established health crisis protocols will be activated" and the person will be taken to a "health center."

These rules will remain in effect "until the government declares an end to the health crisis caused by COVID-19."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
Regional Government of Castilla and Leon published on March 11 the list of preventive measures due to rising number of COVID 19 cases in the region. One of them includes that scheduled healthcare activities in hospital healthcare facilities (consultations, examinations and interventions) may be suspended or limited.

The policy ended on March 14 with the Royal Decree 463/2020 that declared the national state of alarm for the management of the health crisis situation caused by COVID-19. description: Spain on March 19 establishes that hygienic face masks must be labelled with the following information: the company data; product denomination; container content; composition; recommended period of use; essential features including size if relevant; manufacturing batch; place of origin; health warnings; recommendations for use, placement and maintenance; Technical specifications; bacterial filtration efficiency and breathability and final price. Additionally, unit-sale of face masks is only allowed in pharmacies. This is part of a set of measurements to ensure that citizens can access hygienic preventive products in informed and economic conditions.

The Government will distribute 6 million masks from Monday onwards in the transport hubs. description: On May 24, the Spanish Ministry of Health releases recommendations on "the opening to the public of beaches and bathing areas." In this recommendation document, it is urged for "extreme measures of social distancing and hygiene on the beaches" to be followed. Additionally, it "is recommended to clean and disinfect the different facilities such as the railings, the access steps to the water and the showers, as well as the sun loungers, umbrellas, seats, wastebaskets and, in general, urban furniture and recreational facilities." Other recommendations also include insisting "on the need for collective awareness in respect of social distancing" and the advice to avoid "gatherings of more than 15 people."

description:
On June 22, the Government of Spain publishes a "guide with recommendations on the use and maintenance of air conditioning and ventilation systems in buildings and commercial premises." "The document establishes a series of technical criteria to protect public health, with the aim of preventing the spread of COVID-19 in public spaces and premises with mechanical ventilation or air conditioning, such as offices, shopping centers, sports or cultural facilities, among others." Such recommendations include the following:

1. "The guide emphasizes that air renewal is the most important parameter. If possible, a minimum of 12.5 liters [of air] per second (l / s) per occupant is recommended." "To ensure this minimum value," the guide explains that one can either "increase ventilation or reduce the occupation of spaces."

2. The guide emphasizes verifying "that the equipment in charge of air renewal works, at least, in their nominal design conditions and that the possible pressure losses, especially internal to the system, are minimal."

3. The guide recommends "eliminating or reducing air recirculation whenever operating conditions allow it."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On June 8, 2020, The Catalan Ministry of Health announced it is is finalizing arrangements to make compensation payments to health professionals. A plan to support the primary care system will also be launched. The initial investment will be €4.5m, and 436 professionals will be hired in the coming months.

During the pandemic, 3,527 professionals were hired from outside the health system. A commitment has also been made to hire around half of the residents who worked through to the end of May.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
Castilla and Leon (Spain) - Government of Castilla and Leon allocates 20 million euros from the “Emergency COVID 19 Fund” to help provincial governments and city councils that have more than 20,000 inhabits to pay for the expenses generated in social services. July 30, 2020. 

- three million euros to reinforce the care files for dependency and other basic needs (15% of the total fund)
- strengthening of proximity services, such as remote health support, home help, such as program "Crecemos y Conciliamos", to which 3 million euros are allocated (15% of the total fund)
- expenses necessary to cover the needs in the retirement centers for the elderly and people with disabilities: they will serve to reinforce the workforce through new hires or replacements; acquire Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and diagnostic tests for employees and users; finance disinfection measures for facilities and improve safety by distributing spaces and routes to avoid contagion; and carry out small works and the acquisition of equipment for the sectorization or application of contingency plans against COVID-19. 7 million euros (35 percent of the total amount of the extraordinary fund) are allocated for this purpose.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On March 17, the "Spanish Agency for Medicines and Health Products (AEMPS)" establishes "a series of exceptional measures to manage the development of clinical trials during the period of health crisis due to the coronavirus ( COVID-19)." Additionally, these "measures are not specific to clinical trials for the treatment of coronavirus, but affect all clinical trials," and "have the objective of allowing these trials to continue [while also] guaranteeing the safety and well-being of the patients, preserving their validity and avoiding an overload of care in... [health] centers. These measures include:

1. Those responsible for the clinical trial can postpone face-to-face visits or transform them into telephone visits, depending on the characteristics of each trial.

2. Those responsible for the clinical trial can interrupt the recruitment and even the treatment of patients to avoid unnecessary risks and ensure healthcare. 

3. Transfer of patients from one center to another.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 14, the Spanish Ministry of Health promotes a "a ministerial order that makes public and private clinical diagnostic laboratories available to the autonomous communities." According to the order, all "centers, services and health establishments that are not providing service in the National Health System, as well as their personnel, will be at the service of the CCAA." In addition to setting "exceptional measures to strengthen the National Health System and contain the health crisis," the order also  "sets the requirements for carrying out diagnostic tests for the detection of COVID-19," stating that "tests must be prescribed by a physician in accordance with the guidelines, instructions and criteria agreed upon by the competent health authority." Finally, the order requires centers to notify the CCAA of "confirmed COVID-19 cases," leaves the door ajar for regulations on the price of testing, and mandates "that public or private entities that acquire material for diagnostic tests" inform "the competent health authority of the autonomous community in which they are located... the type of material, number of units purchased and destination of use" for such resources.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Community of Madrid, Spain, initiated a testing program for health professionals working in hospitals on April 24, 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: The Ministry of Health and Consumption of the Balearic Islands (Spain) announced that they will monitor the temperature of all incoming arrivals to the island of Formentera.
target_geog_level: One or more cities within a country

description: The Balearic Islands (Spain) "will carry out tests to detect the coronavirus in all works in the 10 slaughterhouses of the Islands."
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: The regional government of the Community of Madrid, Spain, began disinfecting surfaces (handrails, seats, armrests, door handles, and other surfaces) on public transportation (Metro de Madrid, EMT, other urban and intercity buses, Renfe Cercanías and light metros) beginning March 8, 2020. The government also installed automatically opening and closing doors on all train models where it was possible, which was 64% of all trains.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: The Spanish Ministy of Health has advised public transportation providers to desinfect busses on a daily basis, beginning on 10 March 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Spain (Madrid, region) will disinfect all vehicles involved in the scheduled passenger transport on a daily basis starting from March 11 for at least 15 days.
type_text: Disinfection of Public Space
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: The Balearic Islands (Spain) instituted the intensification of daily cleaning and disinfection of public transport.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: The Ministry of Health of Catalonia stated that "All public transport operators will need to increase the hygiene and cleanliness protocols needed to prevent contagion" on the 13th of March of 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On March 19, 2020, the Catalan Government indicates that the following measure will enter into force on March 25, 2020. During the duration of the alarm and health emergency period, health waste generated in hospitals and health centers from the activity care in patients diagnosed or suspected of suffering from Covid19, and who are considered risky waste, Group III, will be segregated and managed as follows: a) Sharp, sharp waste, containing biological fluids and secretions, are they must be collected in 30 and 60-liter containers and duly accredited needles. b) The rest of the waste from health care to these patients, such as PPE equipment, care materials, gauze, probes, empty serum bags, tubing, and others, must be collected in a double gauge bag 220, capacity up to 240 liters and with secure closure.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: Spain (Madrid) announced that it desinfected more than 80% of the streets of the municipalities in the Community of Madrid on March 31
type_text: Street desinfection

description: Spain announces on May 3 that starting from May 4, the wearing of face masks is compulsory in all types of public transport. In case people are not living in the same household but sitting in the same vehicle, they also have to wear the masks in private cars.

Spain announces on May 3 that starting from May 4, businesses must comply with special hygiene measures: if clothing or footwear are sold, each garment, as well as the testers, must be disinfected after each use. A disinfection of the premises will be necessary twice a day, one of them, at its closure. And employee uniforms will have to be washed daily with water over 60 degrees. Customers may not use the toilets except in cases of need. If a safety distance of two meters is not possible, masks will be mandatory. All businesses must make hydroalcoholic gels available to their customers.

On May 14, the Ministry of Health establishes "basic security measures to ensure the health of citizens in swimming pools." Additionally, this safety protocol "will come into force only and exclusively when the Transition Plan towards a new normality establishes that the opening is possible." These measures include "the ventilation of closed spaces, such as changing rooms and bathrooms;" "the disinfection of all the furniture;"maintaining "the treatment and residual disinfection levels in the water; " "[c]apacity and access control," and the creation of"systems for hand [and shoe] disinfection at the entrance" of the facility.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Spanish government is requiring that face masks be used by everyone age six or older in enclosed spaces and public areas where it is impossible to maintain six feet of social distance. The order recommends but does not require mask use by children between age three and five. Those individuals who are engaged in activities that make mask use problematic or those with a medical condition where mask use is contraindicated are excepted from the requirement.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: The Regional Government in Catalonia ordered a lockdown on the towns of Igualada, Vilanova of the Camí, Santa Margarida and Òdena starting from March 13 2020. Disobeying the confinement can lead to fines up to 60,000 euros according to the Civil Protection Act.
target_geog_level: One or more cities within a country
target_city: Jorba, Santa Margarida de Montbui, Vilanova del Camí y Òdena

description: The Generalitat ordered on Thursday night the confinement of the Barcelona municipalities of Igualada, Vilanova del Camí, Santa Margarida de Montbui and Òdena (in total 70,000 inhabitants) to avoid the spread of the largest coronavirus outbreak identified in Catalonia. Since 00:00 this Friday, no one can leave the perimeter guarded by the Mossos d'Esquadra.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On March 14, the Spanish government declared a state of emergency for the nation which includes internal border conditions. Under these conditions, movement between the country's provinces is restricted, only being available if one is "traveling for essential health reasons;" "traveling for essential work, professional, or business reasons;" "traveling to return to ... [one's] family residence;" "traveling ... [to provide] assistance and care of the elderly, dependent, or disabled;" or "traveling due to force majeure or a situation of need."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
In accordance with the primary lockdown measure, on March 14 Spain implements a ban on traveling on public roads unless for the several activities deemed essential as clarified in the aforementioned measure ("To buy essentials from supermarkets or pharmacies," "To go to work," etc.) To maintain compliance, police will install "'fixed and mobile' police checkpoints on roads, in public areas and on public transport," where violators can be "slapped with fines starting at €100 for disobeying the conditions of the state of alert, or [can even face prison time] ... should they 'resist or seriously disobey the authorities or officers when they are carrying out their functions.'" Additionally, only one individual may drive in a car at a time, except when justified ("in the case of people with mobility difficulties," for example), in which case the passenger "sits at the back and on the opposite side from the driver."
 

.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 17, the Government of Spain announces that, starting March 18, “landing in all airports in the [Canary or Balearic] Islands for executive aviation flights, air taxi or operations similar to these, regardless of their origin” is prohibited. Additionally, these restrictions apply to maritime transportation as well, as now “disembarkation is prohibited in the ports located in the territory of the Autonomous Community of the Canary Islands for passengers embarked on ro-ro passenger ships and passenger ships that provide regular line service, with passage on board, originating in the peninsula,” with these same measures applying to the ports of "Palma, Alcúdia, Maó, Ciutadella and Eivissa" of the Balearic Islands.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On March 17, the Government of Spain announces that, starting March 19, “it is prohibited to carry out any type of commercial or private flight, originating from any airport located in the national territory and destination any airport located in the territory of
Canary Islands,” as well as it is “prohibited to carry out any type of commercial or private flight, from any airport located in the national territory and the airports located in the territory of the Balearic Islands.”
These restrictions also carry over to sea ports, where "entry into all the ports of the [Canary or Balearic] Islands of all vessels and pleasure boats used for recreational or sports purposes or in nautical lease (charter), regardless of its origin” is prohibited.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On March 20, authorities in Spain set up about 30,000 roadblocks to prohibit the traveling of residents to secondary homes during the weekend. "If you are caught traveling with families and suitcases to your second location, you will be ordered to return to your home with a fine of between" 601 and 3000 euros.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: As announced April 28, on May 4, the National Government of Spain begins a "de-escalation" plan to lift lockdown restrictions. The beginning of this plan replaces the universal internal border restrictions with asynchronous restrictions more relevant to where each province is at in terms of Covid-19.

description: On March 14, the Spanish government declared a state of emergency for the nation which includes internal border conditions. Under these conditions, movement between the country's provinces is restricted, only being available if one is "traveling for essential health reasons;" "traveling for essential work, professional, or business reasons;" "traveling to return to ... [one's] family residence;" "traveling ... [to provide] assistance and care of the elderly, dependent, or disabled;" or "traveling due to force majeure or a situation of need." UPDATE: On May 4, the National Government of Spain replaces the overarching lockdown (and therefore internal border restrictions) with a 4-phase de-escalation framework that will move asynchronously throughout each province. This means the national internal border restrictions will be replaced by restrictions more relevant to where each province is in Covid-19 resiliance.

The beginning of this plan replaces the universal internal border restrictions with asynchronous restrictions more relevant to where each province is at in terms of Covid-19.


 UPDATE: Starting on 21st June 2020, Spain ends its asymmetric deescalation plan and reopens its internal borders, reestablishing free movement between all provinces and autonomous communities.

description:
Officials in Spain's north-western region of Galicia have re-imposed restrictions on an area of 70,000 people following a Covid-19 outbreak.

Only those travelling for work will be allowed to leave or enter the coastal district of A Marina from midnight on Sunday to Friday. Regional health officials announced  that travel in and out of A Marina would be severely restricted for five days - although people would remain free to move around the area.

description: Government of Castilla and Leon published the list of preventive measures of a coercive nature for the entire population and the territory of the Community of Castilla y León on March 11. Among others, these include restriction of access of companions and visitors to public and private health centers. These are restricted to the minimum necessary to guarantee the right of minimum accompaniment of the patient who requires it, except in individual circumstances in which additional measures of care and socialisation are applied. Visits of minors to health centers are prohibited.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
Government of Castilla and Leon published the list of preventive measures of a coercive nature for the entire population and the territory of the Community of Castilla y León on March 11. Among others, these include restriction of access of companions and visitors to public and private health centers. These are restricted to the minimum necessary to guarantee the right of minimum accompaniment of the patient who requires it, except in individual circumstances in which additional measures of care and socialisation are applied. Visits of minors to health centers are prohibited.

This policy ended on March 14, with the national state of alarm. UPDATE: The original policy was supposed to end on March 26, but it ended on March 14 when Royal Decree 463/2020 that declared the state of alarm on the whole territory of Spain was singed and published.

description: Government of Castilla and Leon published an order on March 13 where the visits to residential centers for public and private senior citizens are suspended, except in individual circumstances in which additional care and humanization measures are applied, to be adopted by the center's management. Moreover, users are forbidden to leave their residence.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On March 14 2020, Spain imposed a nationwide lockdown, ordering its 47 million people to mostly stay in their homes. Additionally, the lockdown ordered the closing of "all non-essential shops ... along with bars, restaurants, cafes and cinemas." This mandate was to stay in affect for 14 days, with extension possible through "parliamentary approval."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Government of Castilla and Leon published an order on March 13 where the visits to residential centers for public and private senior citizens are suspended, except in individual circumstances in which additional care and humanization measures are applied, to be adopted by the center's management. Moreover, users are forbidden to leave their residence. 

The original policy was supposed to end on March 27, but it actually ended on March 14 with the Royal Decree 463/2020 that declared the national state of alarm for the management of the health crisis situation caused by COVID-19. UPDATE: The original policy was supposed to end on March 27, but it actually ended on March 14 with the Royal Decree 463/2020 that declared the national state of alarm for the management of the health crisis situation caused by COVID-19.

description: On March 14, the National Government of Spain announces that, starting March 15, the entire population of the country (around 47 million) will be confined to a lockdown to curb the spread of Covid-19.  Under this lockdown, "citizens can leave their homes ONLY to buy groceries and pharmaceutical products, go to the bank or hospital, ... to take care of dependents/elderly," or walk the dog. Additionally, while "on the street, they must be unaccompanied at all times, and while they can go to work, most workplaces are to be closed to the public until further notice." (Ex. "Bars, restaurants, and shops selling anything but food and other staples must shut down. All leisure and sports activities also have to close, including cinemas, theaters, swimming pools or football grounds.") This lockdown is set to be in place as long as the National State of Alarm is still active.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: President of the Generalitat Quim Torra has announced the confinement of all Catalonia in a line of hardening of the measures to try to contain the contagion of coronavirus.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description: On March 28, the Government of Spain announced that, starting March 30, all nonessential activities will be halted until April 9. This means that nonessential workers who were allowed to go to work under the previous March 15 lockdown measures are now barred from doing so for 2 weeks. In terms of the mandate, all essential activities that will be allowed to continue operation include "those considered necessary for the maintenance of basic social functions (health, security, social and economic wellbeing of citizens)." Additionally, nonessential workers will still "receive their usual salaries but [will] have to make up lost hours at a later date." All other restrictions from the original lockdown procedure (March 15) are still in effect as well.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Additionally, while "on the street, they must be unaccompanied at all times, and while they can go to work, most workplaces are to be closed to the public until further notice." (Ex. "Bars, restaurants, and shops selling anything but food and other staples must shut down. All leisure and sports activities also have to close, including cinemas, theaters, swimming pools or football grounds.") This lockdown is set to be in place as long as the National State of Alarm is still active.
 UPDATE: On March 28, the Government of Spain announced that, starting March 30, "stricter lockdown measures [will be enforced that require] ...  all non-essential workers to stay at home for the next two weeks."

In terms of the mandate, all essential activities that will be allowed to continue operation include "those considered necessary for the maintenance of basic social functions (health, security, social and economic wellbeing of citizens)." Additionally, nonessential workers will still "receive their usual salaries but [will] have to make up lost hours at a later date."  UPDATE: On April 13, the stricter lockdown measures regarding nonessential labor that were compounded onto the original restrictions are lifted.

description: On April 13, the Government of Spain lifts some of the additional restrictions that were put in place on the midnight of March 27. Now, people "in manufacturing, construction and some services are being allowed to return to work, but must stick to strict safety guidelines." As for the rest of the national population, the guidelines imposed on midnight of March 14 are still in effect.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 13, the Government of Spain lifts some of the additional restrictions that were put in place on the midnight of March 27. Now, people "in manufacturing, construction and some services are being allowed to return to work, but must stick to strict safety guidelines." As for the rest of the national population, the guidelines imposed on midnight of March 14 are still in effect. UPDATE: On April 26, the Government of Spain lifted even more restrictions imposed by the March 14 lockdown, this time revolving around the ability for children to play outside.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 21,  Spain's Health Minister Salvador Illa announced that, beginning April 26, restrictions regarding outside activity for children  younger than 14 (imposed under the March 14 lockdown) will be lifted on April 26. Under these lifted restrictions, children are allowed "outside for one hour a day with a parent and must remain within a kilometer, or around 0.6 miles, of their homes." All other restrictions imposed by the March 14 lockdown are still in place.

UPDATE: On April 26, restrictions regarding outside activity for children 14 years old or younger (imposed under the March 14 lockdown) will be lifted.

description: On April 25, Spain’s Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez announces that, starting May 2, major restrictions involving outside activity imposed via the March 14 lockdown will be lifted. Individuals 14 or older, under 70, and non-dependent are allowed to "take one-hour walks, accompanied by one person, once a day within half a mile of their homes, or do sports like riding a bike alone within their city." Additionally, these activities are restricted to two time frames (see curfew category) and social distancing.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 25, Spain’s Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez announces that, starting May 2, major restrictions involving outside activity imposed via the March 14 lockdown will be lifted. Individuals 70 and older, along with "vulnerable adults" ("who may be accompanied by a carer") are allowed to leave their home for exercise.  Additionally, these activities are restricted to two time frames (see curfew category) and social distancing.

description: On April 25, Spain’s Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez announces that, starting May 2, restrictions involving outdoor activity will be lifted for much of the population. Children are still allowed out to play for an hour a day, but now within a different time frame (see curfew category). Social distancing is enforced.

description: On April 28, the Prime Minister of Spain announced that, beginning May 4, the nation would enter a gradual de-escalation period for the country's strict lockdown. As the de-escalation will take place "at a different, yet coordinated, rate" in each province, the beginning of this plan replaces the national lockdown measures that preceded it (additionally, due to the province-centric characteristic of the measure, all advancements in the plan will be coded sub-nationally for each individual province.)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Spain on May 3 announces that starting from May 4, as part of Phase 0 of the 4-phase de-escalation plan, athletes qualified by the Higher Sports Council as being of a high level or of national interest, may carry out training individually, outdoors, and only in the province where they reside. They may freely access, if necessary, those natural spaces in which they must carry out their sporting activities, such as the sea, rivers, or reservoirs. Additionally, trainers are allowed to accompany athletes, and an additional person may be in attendance in the case of paralympic sports.

*As the 4-phase deescalation plan is asynchronous for each national region, whenever Andalusia enters a phase, it's effects will be coded sub- nationally.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On May 4, Andalusia entered Phase 0 of Spain’s 4-phase de escalation plan. Additionally, the lockdown lifting allowing “Individuals 14 or older, under 70, and non-dependent” to "take one-hour walks, accompanied by one person, once a day within half a mile of their homes, or do sports like riding a bike alone within their city" is now included in this phase 0. Due to the asynchronous nature of the de escalation plan, this loosened restriction on lockdown will now be coded subnationally, as how long it lasts locally largely depends on how well Andalusia handles its virus environment. (More info on the curfew side of this policy can be found in the "curfew" category.)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 4, Andalucia transitions to Phase 0. Due to this transition, citizens are now allowed to leave their house to go to visit businesses as long as the business meets a set of specific requirements and the citizen already has an appointment scheduled at said business.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 4, Andalusia enters Phase 0 of Spain’s 4-phase de escalation plan. Due to the asynchronous nature of the de escalation plan, this loosened restriction will now be coded subnationally, as how long it lasts locally largely depends on how well Andalusia handles its virus environment.

Additionally, the lockdown lifting allowing “Individuals 14 or older, under 70, and non-dependent” to "take one-hour walks, accompanied by one person, once a day within half a mile of their homes, or do sports like riding a bike alone within their city" is now included in this phase 0. Due to the asynchronous nature of the de escalation plan, this loosened restriction on lockdown will now be coded subnationally, as how long it lasts locally largely depends on how well where the Valencian Community handles its virus environment. (More info on the curfew side of this policy can be found in the "curfew" category.)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: 4 MAY: Spain on May 3 announces that starting from May 4, as part of Phase 0 of the 4-phase de-escalation plan, athletes qualified by the Higher Sports Council as being of a high level or of national interest, may carry out training individually, outdoors, and only in the province where they reside. They may freely access, if necessary, those natural spaces in which they must carry out their sporting activities, such as the sea, rivers, or reservoirs. Additionally, trainers are allowed to accompany athletes, and an additional person may be in attendance in the case of paralympic sports. Due to the asynchronous nature of the de escalation plan, this loosened restriction on lockdown will now be coded subnationally, as how long it lasts locally largely depends on how well where the Valencian Community handles its virus environment.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
On April 25, Spain’s Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez announces that, starting May 2, major restrictions involving outside activity imposed via the March 14 lockdown will be lifted. Individuals 70 and older, along with "vulnerable adults" ("who may be accompanied by a carer") are allowed to leave their home for exercise.  Additionally, these activities are restricted to two time frames (see curfew category) and social distancing.
 UPDATE: Beginning May 4, the nation enters a gradual, asymmetric de-escalation period for the country's strict lockdown.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 25, Spain’s Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez announces that, starting May 2, restrictions involving outdoor activity will be lifted for much of the population. Children are still allowed out to play for an hour a day, but now within a different time frame (see curfew category). Social distancing is enforced. UPDATE: Beginning May 4, the nation enters a gradual, asymmetric de-escalation period for the country's strict lockdown.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On April 25, Spain’s Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez announces that, starting May 2, major restrictions involving outside activity imposed via the March 14 lockdown will be lifted. Individuals 14 or older, under 70, and non-dependent are allowed to "take one-hour walks, accompanied by one person, once a day within half a mile of their homes, or do sports like riding a bike alone within their city." description: On April 28, the Prime Minister of Spain announced that, beginning May 4, the nation would enter a gradual de-escalation period for the country's strict lockdown. As the de-escalation will take place "at a different, yet coordinated, rate" in each province, the beginning of this plan replaces the national lockdown measures that preceded it (additionally, due to the province-centric characteristic of the measure, all advancements in the plan will be coded sub-nationally for each individual province.) UPDATE: On June 21, the national state of alarm is lifted therefore ending the de-escalation plan.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

The restrictions will last 15 days. Residents are allowed to leave their home for essential errands, such as buying medicine.

description: On May 4, the Valencian Community enters Phase 0 of Spain’s 4-phase de-escalation plan. Additionally, the lockdown exemption "regarding legitimate reasons for leaving the house-" such as "to buy food, basic or pharmaceutical items; to attend medical centres; to go to and from work; [and] to look after children, older people or those with disabilities or who are especially vulnerable-" is now included in this phase. Due to the asynchronous nature of the de escalation plan, this loosened restriction will now be coded subnationally, as how long it lasts locally largely depends on how well where the Valencian Community handles its virus environment.

description: On May 4, The Valencian Community transitions to Phase 0. Due to this transition, citizens are now allowed to leave their house to go to visit businesses as long as the business meets a set of specific requirements and the citizen already has an appointment scheduled at said business.

description: Spain  announces the convening of an Interterritorial Council to address the situation of the coronavirus on Feb 01 due to a confirmed case in La Gomera

description:
The Government agrees to create the Interministerial Coordination Committee in the face of the threat to Public Health caused by the coronavirus

It is a working group in which the situation will be monitored and evaluated and the Government's transversal response will be coordinated in the event of any eventuality that may occur.

The Committee will be chaired by the First Vice President of the Government and Minister of the Presidency, Relations with the Courts and Democratic Memory, and the vice-presidency will be held by the Minister of Health.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Spain recommend holding mass sports competitions with teams from risk areas behind closed doors on March 3. Behind closed doors will be those professional sports competitions where a high presence of amateurs is expected from the coronavirus risk areas, the four regions of Northern Italy (Lombardy, Veneto, Piedmont and Emilia Romagna), China, Japan, South Korea, Iran and Singapore).
type_text: Sport events with high presence of amateur from risk areas will without public

description: As part of its declaration of emergency, Spain on March 14 establishes a set of measurements for its internal transport: the frequency of public transport shall be reduced by at least 50%. This applies to both private and state owned road, rail, air and sea passenger transport services. If for technical or operational reasons the direct application of the percentages established from the first day is not feasible, the quickest possible adjustment of the services should be carried out, which may not last more than five days. (Article 14)
type_text: Restriction on Frequency of Public Transport
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On April 19, the National Government of Spain releases an order that "establishes exceptional measures to guarantee the population's access to" resources necessary to defend against Covid-19." 

This is achieved through establishing "the procedure for setting the amount" at which "sanitary products, as well as those products necessary for the protection of [the population's]... health against COVID-19," will be sold at. Furthermore, "the pricing authority has 48 hours to set the maximum retail price" for these items [i.e. "surgical masks, nitrile gloves, hygienic masks, antiseptics, hydroalcoholic gels and solutions as well as other (medical and non-medical) devices that are considered essential to minimize the risk of COVID-19 spreading among people."]

Additionally, measures are imposed that dictate how to "determine the
information to be established on the labeling of hygienic masks" AND measures are imposed that define the conditions where a unit sale of [surgical] masks can be made to the public" when such masks are not individually packaged.
type_text: While the policy involves increasing access to health resources, it does not involve the government acquiring or distributing more resources, but instead involves the National Government of Spain increasing public access to/comprehension of these resources.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 26th, the department of employment and social policy in Basque country announced a benefit for those who can't afford to pay rent due to unemployment, reduced employment, or loss of income. Their rent can be reduced by 50%, or, depending on the severity of the situation, completely waived during the state of alarm. This benefit can also extend to up to 4 months after the state of alarm is over depending on the severity of the situation.
type_text: The policy reduces/waives rent for those struggling to pay due to effects of COVID-19.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On April 28th, in order to help soften the financial burdens caused by COVID-19, the department of education in Basque Country announced that "in all university studies the grade necessary to access a scholarship will be reduced", "the calculation of academic performance" needed to maintain the scholarship will be more flexible, "and the administration will apply a correction coefficient to" families' "income statement if they suffer from the economic consequences of COVID-19." Additionally, "for the coming year, all university fees will be frozen and" the cost of this second semester will be reduced for those affected by COVID.
type_text: Measures to ensure university fees don't become more of a burden, especially for those who have been affected financially by COVID-19.

description: Spain on May 3 announces that starting from May 4 four islands (La Gomera, La Graciosa, El Hierro —in the Canary Islands— and Formentera —in the Balearic Islands) enter directly into phase 1: the meeting of groups of up to 10 people will be allowed, always keeping the safety distance. Shops of less than 400 meters may open to the public without an appointment, but with a reduction in capacity to 30%. The outdoor markets can also return, with a capacity of 25% of the usual stalls and a third of the influx. In addition, the attendance capacity of the wake is expanded to 15 people.

description: As part of its declaration of emergency, Spain is enforcing a quarantine on the whole country starting March 14 for at least 15 days. [for] all travellers arriving from abroad," with the quarantine's duration being tied to the state of alarm. "Additionally, visitors are "only allowed out for groceries, to visit health centres or in a “situation of need.” "Truck drivers, airplane and ship crews, cross-border workers and health staff working in Spain will be exempt from the quarantine."

description: Effective May 15, passengers arriving in Spain from other countries will be required to quarantine at their home/place of accommodation for the 14 days immediately following their arrival. During the mandatory quarantine period following your arrival in Spain, you will only be allowed to leave your home/accommodation to shop for food, medications, or other basic necessities, to seek medical assistance, or in other very limited emergency circumstances. This all-encompassing quarantine ended on June 21, when restrictions were lifted for "the EU, Schengen member states and a list of approved third countries." UPDATE: The original quarantine was scheduled to stay in effect as long as the national state of alarm was still recognized. This state of emergency ended on June 21, ending the broad-based quarantine by lifting the quarantine restrictions from  "the EU, Schengen member states and a list of approved third countries." However, the rest of the world still needs to abide by these restrictions.
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: On June 21, the Government Spain declared that only individuals entering the country NOT from the EU and Schengen member states (UK included) will be required to be subjected to a 14 day quarantine (with the exception of "basic activities only, such as buying necessary products or for health reasons.") description: On May 12, the Government of Spain announced that, starting May 15, there would be an "ordered ...  two-week quarantine ... [for] all travellers arriving from abroad," with the quarantine's duration being tied to the state of alarm. "Additionally, visitors are "only allowed out for groceries, to visit health centres or in a “situation of need.” "Truck drivers, airplane and ship crews, cross-border workers and health staff working in Spain will be exempt from the quarantine." UPDATE: On June 21, the Government Spain replaced the broad May 15 quarantine mandate by declaring that only individuals entering the country not from the EU or Schengen member states will required to be subjected to the 14 day measure.
type_sub_cat: Quarantine outside the home or government facility (i.e. quarantine in a hotel)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Throughout the pandemic, Spain, like many other countries, accepted the WHO's recommendation for a "14-day period" of isolation as "the norm for covid." However, on September 24, the Government of Spain announces that the "mandatory quarantine for those who are close contacts of covid cases"will be reduced from "14 to 10" days. ("Anyone diagnosed with covid... must still complete the 14 day quarantine.")
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting March 14, Spain's Ministry of Health establishes that the corresponding town councils may proceed to reopen the markets. They'll need to carry out their activity outdoors or for non-sedentary sales on public roads, giving preference to those of food products and basic necessities and ensuring that on the products marketed in them, their non-manipulation is guaranteed for the consumers.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Supermarkets/grocery stores") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Spain (risk areas, Madrid, Victoria, Labastida) recommends carrying out teleworking whenever possible.
Review and update of the plans for continuity of the work activity in case of emergencies. Flexibility in working hours and staggered shifts to reduce worker concentrations. Favouring meetings by videoconference.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is closed/locked down

description: On March 9, the Community of Madrid, Spain, recommended that businesses make plans for continuing their operations in remote spaces. The government promoted video conferencing and flexibility in scheduling.
institution_status: This type of business ("All or unspecified businesses") is allowed to open with no conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On March 12, the president of the Generalitat Valenciana, Ximo Puig, informed a) the closure of cultural centers, museums, theaters, libraries and cinemas. b) The closure of nightclubs, pubs and any other recreational establishment. c) The closure of bars, cafes, restaurants. e) The closure of gambling establishments (e.g. casinos). f) The closure of amusement parks, theme parks and any other center that carries out leisure. g) The closure of gyms, pools and any other sport centers. This measure will enter into force on the 13th of March 2020 and it will initially last 15 days.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is closed/locked down

description:
The regional government of Madrid [Spain] ordered the closure of all non-essential businesses, including "cinemas, nightclubs, concert venues, theatres, gaming houses, casinos, theme parks, gyms and cocktail bars," on March 13, 2020. The order was in place until March 26.

"Supermarkets, fruit and vegetable stores, fishmongers, butchers, bakers, pharmacies, gas stations, tobacconists and newsstands will be open, as well as the food sections of department stores."

In Catalonia In the field of sports, leisure and commercial establishments and activities: a) The closure of ski resorts, cross-country skiing and mountain resorts. b) The closure of all kinds of sports facilities, gyms and sports clubs, both publicly owned as private. c) The closure of theaters, cinemas, nightclubs, discos, pubs, dance halls, concert halls,
karaoke rooms, theater cafes and concert cafes and any other recreational establishment. d) The closure of bars, cafes, restaurants and other restaurants except those that are integrated in a hotel establishment or in residential health or social centers. e) The closure of gambling establishments (recreation halls, casinos, bingo and any other). f) The closure of amusement parks, theme parks and any other center that carries out leisure or leisure activities.
recreation. This measure will enter into force on the 13th of March 2020

description: On March 17, the Spanish Council of Ministers passes a Royal Decree which mandates "extraordinary urgent measures to face the economic and social impact of COVID-19." Of these measures, it is made "impossible to cut off the supply of water, electricity and natural gas to users who are vulnerable, severely vulnerable or at risk of social exclusion." "The regulation also suspends the review of the maximum prices for sale to the public of bottled liquefied petroleum gases, such as butane cylinders, and of the Last Resort Rate (TUR) for natural gas, to prevent them from rising." Finally, the order "automatically extends the term of [electricity social bonuses (what supplies electricity vulnerable members of society)] until September 15, 2020."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Spain announces on May 3 that starting from May 4 shops of less than 400 square meters may be opened to the public, always by appointment, which must be arranged by email or telephone. They must reserve a priority schedule for those over 65 years old, which must coincide with the time frame assigned to them for walks (although in this case it is for those over 70): from 10-12 am  and from 7-8 pm. There can be no more than one customer per employee.

description: From 4 May 2020, all establishments and commercial premises of less than 400 square meters in area that had to lower their shutters on 14 March, following the publication of Royal Decree 463/2020, can be reopened to the public. declaring the state of alarm for the management of the situation of the sanitary crisis of the Covid-19. except for those with an area of ​​more than 400 meterssquares, as well as those that have the character of a shopping center or park commercial, or that are within them without direct and independent access from the outside.
